primary_factors: No accumulating snow forecast during the Monday AM commute (WeatherAPI: ~0")
Primary hazard is residual/refreeze black ice from prior wintry mix + very cold temps (single digits/low teens) reducing salt effectiveness
Road crews likely keep main corridors serviceable, but local/residential streets and school lots may stay slick into first bell
No confirmed neighboring-district closures/delays as of latest checks; official district pages show no Mon 1/26 closure posts
Power outages appear low/scattered (no storm-scale outage signal)
Wind-chill verification conflict: an older Weather.com snapshot showed ≤ -20°F, but it is not confirmed for Mon AM; live NWS could not be retrieved—keeps some upside risk
decision_rationale:
Checklist synthesis and weighting (Meteorology 25%, Safety 20%, History 15%, News 15%, Infrastructure 10%, Power 10%, Web verifier 5%):

1) Agreements across experts: All core ops experts (meteorology/history/safety/news) agree this is NOT an active snowstorm morning for Rockford; the closure mechanism would be residual ice/refreeze + cold, not new snow. They also agree main roads should be passable, with the biggest risk on neighborhood roads, bridges, and parking lots.

2) Disagreements/conflicts: The only major conflict is wind chill. WeatherAPI suggests wind chills around ~0°F to about -5°F for the commute, while a stale Weather.com crawl snapshot showed ≤ -20°F (an auto-closure threshold in your rubric). A tool refresh could not retrieve live NWS (timeout) and could not confirm Monday 5–9 AM hourly rows from Weather.com, so ≤ -20°F is NOT confirmed for the commute. This uncertainty raises probability slightly but does not dominate.

3) Plow timing math: Safety clarified worst window 00:00–04:00 is refreeze/visibility, not snowfall. Assuming no new precip after ~04:00, there are ~3h40m before a ~07:40 bell, plus crews are typically already working before 04:00 on priority routes. That amount of time in Kent County usually prevents full closure, though it can still justify a delay if bus-route spot checks find widespread untreated slickness.

4) Any ice? Yes—moderate risk of black ice/residual slick spots is consistently flagged (safety + infrastructure + history). No meaningful Monday-morning freezing rain is forecast; the ‘light freezing rain’ signal is late Monday night (more a Tuesday concern).

5) Neighboring districts: News intel found no confirmed Mon 1/26 closures/delays on Rockford, GRPS, Kentwood, Cedar Springs, or Forest Hills pages during checks. No ‘3+ neighboring districts closed’ trigger.

6) Power outages: Consumers Energy systemwide shows low outages (scattered). No evidence of a countywide outage event that would override road conditions.

7) Wind chill cross-check: Not confirmed ≤ -20°F for the Monday commute due to data freshness and retrieval issues. Because the only ≤ -20°F evidence is stale/unverified, I do NOT apply the near-automatic closure rule, but I keep some tail risk.

8) What would make this wrong: (a) If live NWS/verified sources show wind chill ≤ -20°F at 6–8 AM, closure odds jump dramatically; (b) if early-morning road checks reveal widespread glazing on bus routes (not just spotty slickness), a 2-hour delay or closure becomes more likely; (c) an unanticipated overnight freezing drizzle event.

Bottom line: With no new accumulation, no confirmed neighbor closures, and only moderate residual-ice risk, a FULL snow day is unlikely. I set 14% (slightly above the team’s ~11% consensus) mainly because infrastructure notes persistent ice in this cold pattern and wind-chill verification remains unresolved.

collaboration.summary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 2.0% spread. Average probability: 11%.
